awd_titl_txt: SpecEES: Dynamic Space Frequency Multiplexing - A New Paradigm for Filterbank Multicarrier Spectrum Access
awd_abstract_narration:
SpecEES: Dynamic Space Frequency Multiplexing - A New Paradigm for Filterbank Multicarrier Spectrum Access

The exponential growth of mobile data traffic has driven wireless communication technologies at an unprecedented pace. However, the amount of available spectrum has not kept up. As the use of spectrum becomes increasingly condensed, it is critical to develop new technologies to improve the efficiency of spectrum utilization. Technologies that can better utilize the limited resources of frequency, time, and energy are needed to enable highly versatile and frequency-agile dynamic spectrum access. The proposed project develops a unique approach termed Dynamic Space Frequency Multiplexing (DSFM) for dynamic spectrum access by optimizing space and frequency utilization in physical-layer and integrating with novel channel coding, multiple access control (MAC) layer and coded caching designs to maximize spectral and energy efficiency. Successful execution of this project will improve spectral efficiency by at least an order of magnitude. The proposed design is posed to meet future 5G challenges such as cell densification and massive Internet-of-things (IoT) due to its great flexibility in supporting multiuser asynchronous communication. This project will provide valuable research opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students. Outcomes of this project will also be tightly integrated into classroom teaching and outreach.

The proposed DSFM design builds upon two complementary technologies -- filter bank multicarrier (FBMC) for frequency multiplexing and massive multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) for spatial multiplexing. FBMC has superior spectral property to that of orthogonal frequency division multiplexing (OFDM) due to a flexible prototype filter whose locality in both time and frequency can be controlled. The emerging technology of massive MIMO offers complementary benefits to that of FBMC through spatial multiplexing. It enables a crucial self-equalization property for FBMC systems that allows for great flexibility in the allocation of subcarrier bandwidth in accordance to dynamic spectrum availability. On the other hand, FBMC offers effective frequency multiplexing needed for practical massive MIMO systems.  The proposed DSFM design will maximize mutual benefits of FBMC and massive MIMO and thus is an exceptional candidate for both spectrum efficient and energy efficient dynamic spectrum access. This project is highly innovative in that it develops (1) novel adaptive prototype filter designs that enable self-equalization of FBMC for massive MIMO networks; (2) hybrid beamforming architectures to improve energy efficiency; (3) low complexity channel coding and decoding algorithms for high spectral and energy efficiency communications; (4) cache-aided DSFM carrier aggregation for improving spectral and energy efficiency; (5) DSFM-enabled dynamic MAC layer schemes; (6) city-scale testbed validation using the National Science Foundation (NSF) Platforms for Advanced Wireless Research (PAWR).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project proposed Dynamic Space Frequency Multiplexing (DSFM) building upon two complementary technologies -- filter bank multicarrier (FBMC) and massive MIMO, together with new caching technology. The outcomes of this project are as follows.
 
First, we solved important challenges in using FBMC prototype filter for DSFM. In particular, we studied the channel estimation in the uplink of FBMC systems. A new pilot structure and a joint multiuser channel estimation method were developed for FBMC. The proposed pilot can accommodate a larger number of training signals within the same bandwidth, improve the spectral efficiency, and relax the pilot contamination problem. Analytical expressions of the Cramer-Rao lower bound and mean square error were derived for the proposed method. Moreover, we studied the design of downlink precoder for FBMC-based massive MIMO with imperfect channel reciprocity. We theoretically analyzed the performance of this precoder with imperfect CSI and channel reciprocity calibration errors. Our results show that the proposed precoder leads to superior performance compared to OFDM.
 
Second, we proposed new design of distributed DSFM networks that employ FBMC and massive MIMO. In particular, (1) the above mentioned channel estimation approach was applicable to massive MIMO with both co-located and distributed antennas; (2) we investigated the channel equalization in FBMC-based massive MIMO and propose a practical two-stage equalization technique that is highly effective in both co-located and distributed antennas; (3) we took into account the equalizer length in the design procedure to achieve an equalizer integrated by the power delay profile estimation; (4) we formulated FBMC-based cell-free massive MIMO and investigated channel estimation and equalization; (5) we derived the statistical characteristics of the estimation errors of our proposed channel estimator and incorporated them into our proposed equalizers to tackle the imperfect CSI effects.
 
Third, we proposed low complexity channel coding for high spectral efficiency communications. We showed superior performance of nonbinary LDPC codes compared to binary LDPC codes for multi-carrier systems for which an iterative receiver was designed under imperfect channel estimation. We considered both pilot-aided frequency domain and time-domain channel estimation using basis expansion model (BEM). The latter shows excellent performance for channels with a Doppler frequency of up to 1000Hz. Moreover, we designed neural network-based equalizer that can integrate seamlessly with general channels codes to effectively remove inter-symbol-interference for frequency-selective channels. Such equalizers learn to adapt to unknown channels and can take full advantage of the soft information provided by the channel codes.
 
Fourth, we proposed cache-aided DSFM carrier aggregation for improving spectral/energy efficiency. Note that a large wideband network which can be decomposed into multiple smaller (narrowband) networks with different topologies. First, we studied caching networks with various topologies including the three-tier (small-cell, combination networks) and Device-to-Device (D2D) topologies. Moreover, we considered general network whose topologies are unknown. We designed achievable schemes and characterizing converse on all types of networks. Second, we addressed the high complexity problem in caching by focusing on the coded/uncoded D2D caching networks using realistic demand distributions. We designed a novel achievability based on a new combinatorial approach called packet type-based design. Surprisingly, our design achieves the optimal rate. Third, we extended the file retrieval problem to function and private file retrieval problems with private caches. Here, we consider multiple topologies and derived both achievability and converses, many of which are optimal.
 
Fifth, we proposed DSFM-enabled dynamic MAC layer schemes. In particular, we designed distributed scheduling scheme which does not require central controllers, making proposed protocols also secure. We developed a new stochastic optimization framework and novel solutions based on Lyapunov and game theories that achieve an asymptotically optimal solution of this well-known open problem. Moreover, we proposed using Carrier Sensing (CS) for distributed interference management where spectrum is shared by multiple uncoordinated operators. We characterized challenges in using traditional CS and propose enhanced CS protocols to address these challenges. Using stochastic geometry, we developed a general framework for downlink coverage probability analysis in the presence of CS.  
 
Sixth, we proposed city-scale testbed validation using POWDER (the Platform for Open Wireless Data-driven Experimental Research). We presented a design and implementation of the modulation schemes using different waveforms such as orthogonal time frequency space (OTFS) and OFDM. We performed experiments in POWDER over-the-air indoor environment with emulated Doppler model using software-defined radios and compared the performance between these two modulation schemes.
 
The proposed project is unique in the broader scope of dynamic spectrum access. Successful execution of the proposed project will improve spectral efficiency by at least an order of magnitude. Moreover, the proposed DSFM based Massive MIMO network is posed to meet future 5G and beyond challenges such as cell densification and massive Internet-of-things (IoT) due to its great flexibility in supporting multiuser asynchronous communication. The PIs have incorporated the research outcomes into courses such as Software Radios, Digital Communications, Information Theory, Error Control Coding, and Network Security.
